description: Cognitive trap questions - tests structural trap detection across 13 categories

questions.question: A bat and a ball cost $1.10 in total. The bat costs $1.00 more than the ball. How much does the ball cost in cents?
A notebook and pen cost $5.50 together. The notebook costs $5.00 more than the pen. How much does the pen cost in cents?
A hammer and nail cost $10.10 total. The hammer costs $10 more than the nail. What does the nail cost in cents?
Coffee and a muffin cost $4.40 total. The coffee costs $4 more than the muffin. What does the muffin cost in cents?
A lily pad doubles in size every day. If it takes 48 days to cover the entire lake, how many days does it take to cover half the lake?
Bacteria doubles every hour. If it fills a jar in 24 hours, when is the jar half full?
A virus spreads by doubling infected people each day. If everyone (1 million people) is infected on day 20, on which day were 500,000 people infected?
If 5 machines make 5 widgets in 5 minutes, how many minutes does it take for 100 machines to make 100 widgets?
If 3 workers can paint 3 walls in 3 hours, how many hours does it take 9 workers to paint 9 walls?
If 8 printers print 8 pages in 8 seconds, how many seconds for 1 printer to print 1 page?
A car drives to a destination at 30 mph and returns at 60 mph. What is the average speed for the entire round trip in mph?
Walking uphill at 2 mph and downhill at 6 mph on the same path. Average speed for round trip in mph?
A fair coin has landed heads 10 times in a row. What is the probability the next flip is heads? Answer as a percentage.
A roulette wheel has landed on red 20 times in a row. What is the probability the next spin is red? (Assume 50/50 for simplicity.) Answer as percentage.
A drawer contains red, blue, and green socks. What is the minimum number of socks you must pull out (without looking) to GUARANTEE you have a matching pair?
A box has black, white, red, and blue marbles. What is the minimum marbles to draw (blindfolded) to GUARANTEE 2 of the same color?

A disease affects 1 in 1000 people. A test is 99% accurate (99% true positive, 99% true negative). If you test positive, what's the probability you actually have the disease? Round to nearest percent.

1% of cars are red sports cars. A witness correctly identifies car color 80% of the time. A witness says the car in an accident was a red sports car. Probability it actually was red? Round to nearest percent.
How many trailing zeros does 25! (25 factorial) have?
How many trailing zeros does 100! (100 factorial) have?
How many times do the hour and minute hands of a clock overlap in a 12-hour period?
How many times do clock hands overlap in 24 hours?
There are 2 envelopes with money. One has twice the other. You pick one and find $100. Should you switch? YES (switch is better), NO (staying is better), or INDIFFERENT (same expected value)?
Monty Hall problem: You pick door 1. Host opens door 3 (has goat). Should you switch to door 2? YES or NO.
A store raises prices by 25% then offers a 25% discount. Is the final price HIGHER, LOWER, or SAME as original?
Stock drops 50% then gains 50%. Is your investment now HIGHER, LOWER, or SAME as original?
A product's price increased by 20% and then decreased by 20%. What is the net change as a percentage? (negative if decrease)
Mary is twice as old as Ann was when Mary was as old as Ann is now. If Mary is 24, how old is Ann?
A woman has two children. At least one is a boy born on Tuesday. What's the probability both are boys? Round to nearest percent.
In a room of 23 people, what's the approximate probability that at least 2 share a birthday? Round to nearest 10%.

Linda is 31, single, outspoken, very bright. She majored in philosophy and was deeply concerned with discrimination and social justice. Which is MORE LIKELY? (A) Linda is a bank teller. (B) Linda is a bank teller and active in the feminist movement. Answer A or B.
Tom is athletic, 6'2", and competitive. Which is more probable? (A) Tom plays sports. (B) Tom plays basketball and is on a professional team. Answer A or B.
A die is rolled 6 times. Which sequence is MORE LIKELY? (A) 3-1-4-1-5-9 (B) 6-6-6-6-6-6. Answer A or B or EQUAL.

Monty Hall: 3 doors, 1 car, 2 goats. You pick door 1. Host (who knows what's behind doors) opens door 3 showing a goat. What's the probability of winning if you SWITCH to door 2? Answer as fraction or percentage.
Monty Hall: 3 doors, 1 prize. You pick door 1. Host opens door 2 (no prize). Is SWITCHING to door 3 better, is STAYING with door 1 better, or are they EQUAL?

Three cards: one red on both sides, one blue on both sides, one red/blue. You pick a card randomly and see red. What's the probability (as a percentage, round to nearest whole number) the other side is also red?
